title: Big Break Regional Shoreline Science Hike - KQED
name: Big Break Regional Shoreline Science Hike - KQED
description: The water flowing past Big Break Regional Shoreline through the Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers drains half of California's watershed, and creates the largest estuarine environment on Pacific shores. This "Inland Coast" is home to 70 species of birds, and provides valuable habitat for beavers, muskrats, and river otters.

properties.name: 10a. Otter Scat Dissection
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4911254966"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4141/4911254966_2381fe7c89_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Carnivorous otters making pit stops as they cross the road leave behind evidence of what they ate for dinner. (video)

properties.name: 10b. Otter Freeway
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867165498"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4121/4867165498_f10cdebcf5_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - White smudges along the darker gray asphalt mark a freeway where otters cross from one side of the road to the other. Mud and musk from their bellies gets dragged across the roadway, showing their path. They stop occasionally to leave little scat packages for the curious hiker to dissect.

properties.name: 10c. Otter Scat
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866548895"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4142/4866548895_1c7ddbc4c9_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The shells, scales, or feathers from recent otter dinners can be found in the scat left behind. The orange bits you can see here are crawdad shells.

properties.name: 10d. Otter Scat Close-Up
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866549165"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4140/4866549165_72db035062_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - A closer inspection might reveal some bones and even an occasional fish scale. Once in a while you might find feathers, evidence of a successful catch of a duck or grebe.

properties.name: 11a. Dragonfly
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866556645"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4102/4866556645_c384f00627_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - A variegated meadowhawk (Sympetrum corruptum) finds respite on a spent yerba mansa blossom.

properties.name: 11b. Vivid Dancer Damselfly
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4876923943"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4100/4876923943_47b630a303_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The wings of this azure damsel fly flutter a silvery color as it flies. in 2009, the vivid dancer damselfly was named the state insect of Nevada, blue and silver being the state's colors. The damselfly is found in other states as well, California being one. Photo: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/rwolf/1220496171/">Ron Wolf</a>.

properties.name: 12a. Walnut Tree Surprises
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4910504595"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4099/4910504595_6412961bfc_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Fallen nuts gathered along the trail can become a simple art project. (video)

properties.name: 12b. Black Walnuts
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867169034"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4116/4867169034_bf65c5e984_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Hikers can keep an eye out for these small, dark nuts on the ground. They are from the California black walnut tree (Juglans californica), and while not grown commercially for human consumption, they are an important source of food for wildlife.

properties.name: 12c. Black Walnuts
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866552745"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4096/4866552745_7400209194_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Before they fall from the trees, black walnuts grow encased in a thick green husk.

properties.name: 12d. Walnut or Barn Owl?
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866564451"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4123/4866564451_c510a3dbcb_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Crack a black walnut open and you'll find an inside that resembles an owl face. Try pressing them on an ink pad and making owl-face stamps.

properties.name: 12e. Black Walnut Tree
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866554001"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4096/4866554001_e61a8a1662_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The California black walnut is a common ornamental tree and grows well in areas like the Delta with a ready supply of moving water.

properties.name: 12f. Walnut Tree Bark
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867169384"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4115/4867169384_f657f624e7_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The bark of the California black walnut is notched and rugged.

properties.name: 12g. Marsh Creek
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867166712"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4095/4867166712_b37a6e5e51_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The Big Break trail meets up with Marsh Creek and another 8 miles of associated trail. We end our hike here, but you can continue by foot or bicycle through more miles of East Bay Regional Park.

properties.name: 1a. First Steps
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867179492"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4098/4867179492_b08e553f2c_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The trail at Big Break welcomes bikes and wheelchairs as well as feet. Several miles down the road, it connects with other paved East Bay Regional Park trails, making it a nice starting point for a day's bicycle journey as well as a walk along the delta.

properties.name: 2a. Culvert
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867152700"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4076/4867152700_925baf04d2_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Not long ago, this culvert was thick with blackberries. To bring it back to a wetland state, the channel was graded, letting water in from the delta. Shorebirds found the wetland the very next day. Now visitors see tule and cattails and even small fish. A lesson that sometimes simple, low budget restorations can do the trick; as long as they open up habitat, the critter will show up.

properties.name: 3a. Beavers, Keep Out
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867157332"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4075/4867157332_6ce17434b5_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Short fences around cottonwood trees keep them from falling victim to the park's beavers.

properties.name: 3b. Beavers, Keep Out, Close-up
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867157680"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4102/4867157680_85a3d86a41_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - A good look at some beaver damage. If they were to chew the bark around the entire girth of the tree, the tree would die--if it hadn't already been knocked over and used to build a beaver den.

properties.name: 4a. Green Delta
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866540595"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4074/4866540595_db757942b1_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - A pier over the delta provides a fine fishing and birding spot. On a clear day, you can see all the way to the Sierras. Watch the birds as they land and you'll notice that they avoid landing on the algae. To a shore bird, the algae appears from above to be a land, not water, and therefore diminishes the bird's potential habitat.

properties.name: 4b. Green Delta, Close-up
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866540269"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4073/4866540269_d93653a5b5_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The algae floating in here in the delta is mostly non-native species, much of it Brazilian water weed that's made its way to the Delta from home aquariums. Once here, it finds an accommodating habitat and blooms, affecting oxygen levels in the water and driving fish populations away.

properties.name: 5a. The Buzz About Mosquitoes
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4911098714"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4080/4911098714_9bfcb05389_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Naturalist Mike Moran explains that the bias against mosquitoes is purely human, as many other members of the Delta ecosystem relish them. (video)

properties.name: 5b. Mosquitoes
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867157032"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4119/4867157032_84572ea553_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - A cloud of buzzing mosquitoes hovers over the water near the shore.

properties.name: 6a. Swainson's Hawk
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4876923499"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4098/4876923499_40f2601efb_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Unlike its more common red-tailed cousin, the Swainson's hawk (Buteo swainsoni) migrates up to 10,000 miles to winter breeding grounds in South America, congregating by the thousands to make the trip. While Swainson's resembles the lighter plumages of the red-tailed hawk, it is distinguished by the pattern under its wings--white shoulders with dark flight feathers--and a darker tail with indistinct barring.  Photo: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/rwolf/4051585431/">Ron Wolf</a>.

properties.name: 6b. Red-Tailed Hawk
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4876923433"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4097/4876923433_076fac7d15_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - This red-tailed hawk, in comparison, has brown and white barring under its wings, on contrast with the Swainson's white. And of course, it bears its namesake red tail. Photo: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/rwolf/1465945093/">Ron Wolf</a>.

properties.name: 6c. Common Yellowthroat
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4877533726"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4101/4877533726_cf938706a8_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The Common Yellowthroat (Geothlypis trichas) has a distinctive witchety-witchety-witch song, and is more often heard than seen. This small songbird is often found in wetlands. frequenting the areas long the water's edge. Photo: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/rwolf/327885838/">Ron Wolf</a>.

properties.name: 6d. Sandhill Crane
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4876923851"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4137/4876923851_10b8ab7931_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - These magnificent birds can be up to five feet tall, with a six foot wingspan. Cranes residing in Canada and Alaska migrate to northern California, and can be seen during the winter months in many areas around the Delta and the Central Valley. Photo: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/rwolf/2039154777/">Ron Wolf</a>.

properties.name: 7a. Sedges Have Edges...
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4910628921"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4140/4910628921_faa2b09a29_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - With all these different plants waving in the marshy wind, how can you tell which is which? In this video, Naturalist Mike Moran rhymes his way to plant identification.

properties.name: 7b. Rushes vs. Sedges
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866558895"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4097/4866558895_d51ebcedd5_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - A bit of hands-on study showing what Naturalist Mike Moran means when he says &quot;Sedges have edges, and rushes are round. Grasses are hollow from the tip to the ground.&quot;

properties.name: 7c. Rushes vs. Sedges, Cross Section
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867174554"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4082/4867174554_70342f0d84_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - A cross section view of a rush stem (left) and a sedge stem (right).

properties.name: 7d. Waving Tules
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866559707"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4139/4866559707_e45bdaf7b7_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - These waving green stems are often referred to as tule grass, but tule is actually a rush (meaning its round stems are not hollow like those of a grass). Ohlone and Miwok people used tules to make canoes which they used to get around San Francisco bay.

properties.name: 7e. Tule Seeds
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866559105"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4134/4866559105_72ac73b918_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Tules are topped with distinctive brown flowers that produce seed heads.

properties.name: 7f. Sedge
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867177780"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4117/4867177780_3318b77d90_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - This sedge plant has set up house along the water's edge, a common place to find sedges. This photo shows the edges of the plant's triangular stems. Sedges, like tules, flower at their tip tops and develop brown seed heads.

properties.name: 7g. Sedge Seeds
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866562235"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4080/4866562235_f2e7c0ee49_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - A closer view of the seed heads atop a sedge.

properties.name: 7h. Cattails
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867153198"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4136/4867153198_3c938ffb84_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Cattails are a common sight in North American wetlands, and they are often the first plants to colonize a muddy area that has been cleared of other plants. The brown cylinder at the top is actually a conglomeration of many tiny flowers, which turn into seeds attached to a wisp. Cattail fluff was used during WWII as stuffing for life jackets, because it is quite buoyant. Native Americans used the fluff to line papooses and wove the leaves into walls and mats to waterproof them.

properties.name: 7i. Close-up of a Cattail Flower
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866538099"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4138/4866538099_b324461485_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Cattail flowers become tiny seeds attached to a wisp of fluff that carries them through the air.

properties.name: 7j. Rabbitsfoot Grass
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867176970"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4101/4867176970_a83df228f2_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Rabbitsfoot grass (Polypogon monspeliensis) is recognizable by its bushy seed stalk. It is a hardy plant, and grows as an invasive species in many places throughout North America.

properties.name: 8a. Unexpected Birding Hotspot
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4911129516"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4101/4911129516_fd9016a9eb_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Big Break is a birder's paradise, with over 200 species throughout the year. On a good day along this trail, a skilled birder can probably find between 30 and 60 species in a couple of hours. (video)

properties.name: 8b. An Unlikely Haven
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866545717"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4081/4866545717_c0d86034db_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The wastewater treatment plant provides a haven for birds at Big Break. The open water attracts shorebirds and the fencing keeps neighbors' pets away. Visitors can spot local birds here as well as many migratory species.

properties.name: 8c. A View of Mt. Diablo from the Ponds
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866545951"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4140/4866545951_0f440e315f_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The wastewater ponds also offer birds--and hikers--a nice view of nearby Mt. Diablo, another stopping point for many migrating birds.

properties.name: 8d. Caspian Terns
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866564257"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4122/4866564257_aeb5093b62_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Caspian terns resemble large gulls, though their red bills make them distinct. Many of the terns in California are migrants from the Pacific Northwest, wintering over in warmer climes. Caspian terns are found on every continent except Antarctica, though their population in Africa and Europe has declined due to disturbances to their nesting sites.

properties.name: 8e. Black-Necked Stilts
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4876923555"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4099/4876923555_c1ca1e6e88_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The elegant birds spend summers in California, and here in the Delta, they enjoy the shallow waters of the floodplain. Perhaps the most striking feature of these birds is their long, graceful legs, with a length second only to flamingos in proportion to the size of their bodies. Photo: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/rwolf/3109412551/">Ron Wolf</a>.

properties.name: 8f. Killdeer
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4877533846"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4098/4877533846_c9fe411533_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The killdeer is a shorebird, but it's managed to adapt to lots of human-made environments, too, and is now found all over North America. Their handsome black breast stripe makes them distinctive, as well as their call, a <i>kill-deer</i> after which they're named. They're also notable for their gait, skittering across the ground. stopping to look for insects, drilling down to get them, then skittering on.  Photo: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/rwolf/2292637463/">Ron Wolf</a>.

properties.name: 9a. Field of Yerba Mansa
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867174150"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4095/4867174150_91c4c4aa60_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Despite its scientific name (Anemopsis californica), yerba mansa is native to the American southwest, primarily in New Mexico. It now grows well in wet, marshy areas like the Delta. Though there is no documentation of it having a sedative effect, it is sold as a tincture similar to echinacea by some herbal remedy companies.

properties.name: 9b. Yerba Mansa Inflorescence
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866557393"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4093/4866557393_036080ebbb_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Don't be fooled: the large white petals aren't part of the yerba mansa flower, but rather its inflorescence, a flower-like structure that's really a collection of small flowers. The true buds are made of the tiny white petals that make a small tower of flowers in the center.

properties.name: 9c. Salt Heliotrope
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4867170828"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4074/4867170828_cc8457baa2_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Also known as seaside heliotrope or quail plant, salt heliotrope likes briny soils, which makes it a good candidate for this area where two rivers meet the sea.

properties.name: 9d. Salt Heliotrope
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866554301"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4079/4866554301_5b7cb33120_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - Tiny purple and yellow flowers bloom in rows on the salt heliotrope, and the plant sports thick, spade-shaped leaves.

properties.name: 9e. Marsh Monkeyflower
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866560273"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4114/4866560273_079450773b_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - The marsh monkey flower, also known as seep monkey flower (Mimulus guttatus) is one of many monkey flowers found in California. This species in distinguished by its love of wetlands. Without adequate water, the flowers dry up and disappear.

properties.name: 9f. Marsh Monkeyflower Blossom
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866560021"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4094/4866560021_79f5aef7b0_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - A close up of the marsh monkeyflower (Mimulus guttatus) reveals its characteristic red freckles along the outer sides of its yellow petals.

properties.name: 9g. Starthistle
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866555617"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4099/4866555617_da6d4e2a8f_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - This invasive species is referred to as a pest by many wildlife biologists, and its prockly flowers only add to its lack of desirability. Starthisle often takes root after soil has been disturbed, and then grows quickly, blocking out chances for other species to regain a foothold.

properties.name: 9h. Look Out for Starthistle
properties.description: <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/kqedquest/4866555893"><img src="http://static.flickr.com/4134/4866555893_8008caeba7_m.jpg"/></a><br/><br/> - When you see this weedy-looking plant with its forked leaves, steer clear to avoid scraping your legs on its spikes.

properties.name: Big Break Regional Shoreline Exploration
